newsitem.title: UK: Iraqi opposition welcomes resumption of oil export.
newsitem.headline: Iraqi opposition welcomes resumption of oil export.

text.p: The Iraqi National Congress, the umbrella group for Iraqi opposition parties, on Tuesday welcomed the resumption of Iraqi oil exports under the U.N. oil-for food deal, but called for strict monitoring to prevent abuse of the agreement.

"We welcome the fact that Saddam has finally implemented (U.N. Resolution) 986 but the U.N. must ensure that the resolution is implemented as intended and humanitarian aid is delivered to the Iraqi people, especially those blockaded by the regime in Iraqi Kurdistan and southern Iraq," said Ahmad Chalabi, President of the London-based INC, in a statement.

The statement said that careful international monitoring, including the positioning of U.N. monitors in parts of Iraq where they are not currently present, was necessary to ensure that the agreement was not open to abuse.
The INC warned against the misappropriation of oil revenues by the regime for arms purchases of for the personal use of President Saddam Hussein and his family.

"With the Iraqi regime's history of lies and deceit, continued international vigilance is necessary to prevent Saddam from cheating or twisting the resolution to strengthen his regime," the statement said.
Under the U.N. deal signed in May, Iraq will be allowed to sell $2 billion worth of crude oil for six months to buy food and medicines.

The Iraqi media reported celebrations in the northern Iraqi oil centre of Kirkuk on Tuesday after Saddam Hussein pushed the button to start the first Iraqi exports since the August 1990 invasion of Kuwait.
But Turkish oil officials said that a technical fault had so far prevented the flow of oil through a pipeline to the Mediterranean export port of Ceyhan.
